content.text: Ensure the bottoms of both masses are at the same level
Pull both masses down through a short distance and release them at the same time
Watch the oscillations of the masses. The masses initially oscillate in phase, then out of phase and then back in phase
The number of oscillations of mass S from release until the masses are back in phase for the first time is \(n_0\)
Determine and record \(n_0\)
Add a mass of \(30\mathrm{g}\) to mass S. The added mass is \(M.\)
Record \(M.\)
M =

Determine and record \(n.\)

Vary \(M\) by changing the number of \(10\mathrm{g}\) masses added to mass S and determine \(n.\) Do not use \(M = 0.\)
Repeat until you have five sets of values of \(M\) and \(n.\)
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(N.\) Also include values of \(N^3\) to three significant figures
Plot a graph of \(N^3\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(M\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line

Use the scissors to cut out the rectangles

The time between placing A on the water and the two edges meeting is \(T_{\mathrm{A}}\)
Place A flat on the water
Determine \(T_{\mathrm{A}}\)
